title: Academics responsible for wokeness in universities amid antisemitism crisis
description: The Australian’s Education Editor Natasha Bita says universities must prioritise student safety amid concerns about wokeness in universities.   “Student safety needs to be prioritised,” Ms Bita told Sky News host James Macpherson.  “To be fair, the government has set up a student Ombudsman and has been on at the universities.”

title: Albanese government ‘afraid’ of what a Royal Commission will uncover
description: Former Labor MP Michael Danby says the Labor government has avoided a Royal Commission as they are “afraid” of what it may uncover.  “The director general of ASIO said … the primary source of fear in the security services was Islamist terrorism,” Mr Danby told Sky News Australia.   “What did the government do about it since August?  “That’s what they are afraid will be uncovered.”

title: ‘Another activist platform’: Taxpayer-funded arts group slammed over Israel controversy
description: Sky News contributor Karalee Katsambanis discusses an arts organisation receiving pressure to dump its ambassador for multiple inflammatory posts made about Israel.   “This is a taxpayer-funded event, and that is disgraceful,” Ms Katsambanis told Sky News host James Morrow.  “It’s shocking, they’re quite willing to cancel, when it’s the other way.  “It will just become yet another platform for activists that are not interested in anything else apart from the destruction of Israel.”

title: ‘A real problem’ faces Brigitte Macron in upcoming defamation case
description: Sky News contributor Sophie Elsworth weighs in on a Paris court finding 10 people guilty of cyberbullying France's First Lady, Brigitte Macron.  “This has been a real problem for the First Lady because these conspiracy theories have run wild online and they have not been able to squash them,” Ms Elsworth told Sky News host James Macpherson.   “This is the first part of this case because, as we know, there is also a defamation case which the First Lady has taken out against US podcaster Candace Owens, who has claimed some of the same things.”

title: ‘Wait and see’: Paris court guilty verdict will be a ‘very interesting watch’
description: Sky News contributor Sophie Elsworth analyses the Paris court verdict on 10 people being found guilty of cyberbullying France’s First Lady Brigitte Macron.  “We have to wait and see of course because there’s a court trial happening,” Ms Elsworth told Sky News host James Macpherson.  “It will be very interesting to watch.”

title: ‘Bitterly cold’ conditions in UK is not ‘deterring’ illegal migrants
description: Sky News contributor Sophie Elsworth analyses the migrant crisis in the United Kingdom with Sky News host James Macpherson.  “It has been a shocking start … it is freezing here in the UK,” Ms Elsworth said.  “That is not deterring these illegal migrants from crossing the channel.”

title: Keir Starmer’s government being ‘too soft’ on illegal migration
description: Sky News contributor Sophie Elsworth says the UK Labour Party will continue to “struggle” with handling migration in 2026.   “There is definitely a feeling among the British public that the government is being too soft on allowing these illegal migrants to arrive here firstly, and to stay here,” Ms Elsworth told Sky News host James Macpherson.  “This is going to be a problem that continues in 2026, and one that I don’t think the Starmer government will be able to shake.”

title: Albanese government cut funding to counterterrorism group prior to Bondi Beach massacre
description: Former Liberal senator Hollie Hughes says one of the AFP’s groups handling counterterrorism had been disbanded prior to the Bondi Beach massacre.   “One of the AFP's groups that was supposed to be looking over counterterrorism in fact had lost funding recently and had been disbanded,” Ms Hughes said.  “Albanese’s government has been absolutely instrumental in cutting programs prior to this massacre occurring that were supposed to be overseeing counterterrorism in all its forms.”

title: Australia facing the ‘highest volatility’ in energy prices of any OECD countries
description: Energy and Resource analyst Saul Kavonic says Australia now faces the “highest volatility” in energy prices of any OECD country in the world.

title: Woman sent death threats after refusing plane seat swap request
description: Former NSW senator Hollie Hughes reacts to a woman receiving death threats after refusing to swap seats on a plane so a father could sit by his kids.  “When she politely refused, he then proceeded to act worse than a toddler,” Ms Hughes said.  “I’m with the woman … why would you voluntarily, after paying for an aisle seat, go put yourself in the middle seat?”

title: ‘My heart goes out’: Winton Mayor on flooding in Far North Queensland
description: Winton Shire Mayor sits down with Sky News host James Macpherson to go over the flooding hitting Far North Queensland.  “My heart goes out to our shires and our neighbouring shires,” Ms White said.  “It is a bloody tough situation they are in at the moment.”

title: Labor’s net zero policy has ‘ridiculously ambitious targets’
description: Energy and Resource analyst Saul Kavonic says Labor’s net zero policy has “ridiculously ambitious targets”.  Mr Kavonic told Sky News host Peta Credlin that the target “can’t be met”.  “But all the central planning that is being done by the regularity bodies presume that the target is going to be met.”

title: Concerns over Albanese's handling of counter-terrorism amid calls for a royal commission
description: Concerns are being raised about the Albanese government's decision to disband a counter-terrorism group within the Australian Federal Police.  The disband came shortly before the Bondi massacre.   The government's commitment to addressing antisemitism and terrorism threats are being publicly questioned by the Australian population.

title: Labor accused of contradicting itself over counter-terrorism laws
description: Concerns are being raised about the Albanese government's decision to disband a counter-terrorism group within the Australian Federal Police.  Suggestions are being made around the government's fund cuts for counter-terrorism programs.  These cuts contradict their public statements about supporting intelligence agencies.

title: ‘It’s an illusion’: International law in question after US captures Venezuelan President
description: Townhall.com Senior Columnist Kurt Schlichter questions the effectiveness of international law.  “International law is a guy with a rifle standing there; international law enforcement is whether you can move him or not. It’s an illusion, it’s childish,” Mr Schlichter told Sky News host James Morrow.  “America's interests are America's interests.”
